column4: Actually, if there's any reference documentation for PAM that's newer than the 2006 stuff on kernel.org, that'd be helpful.
so you are SSHing to your phone?
I am ssh'ing to my home server from work, and the password I enter is the verification code that is displayd on the Google authenticator.
not seen that, what client are you using?
I installed libpam-google-authenticator and added the requisite lines to /etc/pamd/common-auth.
xorg edgers has an update ppa (less fresh more stable)
I will try to add the xorg-edgers PPA and see if it causes the same trouble.
if you just install the driver, then remove it then its ok :)
I'm here because of a failed installation of 290.10 from Nvidia just so I can do CUDA and OpenCL.  Looks like I can do those if I give up graphics. :-)
have you tried an xorg.conf file?
I let nvidia-xconfig build one but it did not work.
same place, same in all distros
if you run:   sudo nvidia-xconfig    it will make one for you, you can always drop to root recovery console to fix if it makes issues
I just ran sudo nvidia-xconfig, I'm going to reboot that box and see what happens.

sorry about that -- was running xchat on that box, heh.  Anyway, the kernel log tells me there's some other driver in the way.  How do I see what kernel modules are installed, and remove them?  modprobe and friends?
try blacklisting nouveau and nv
just by adding "blacklist nouveau" to /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.conf ?
if you like, you could even make your own file in the modprobe.d folder and it willwork (must have .conf extension)
np man
if you add the command to start the server in /etc/rc.local   (remember to background it with &) it will run at startup
so something akin to "su - minecraft screen" with the proper .screenrc should do it?
sounds ok if that does it, remember to background it with an ampersand, or the boot will hang
I will remember to background it, and put in a few echos so I can see if I forget. :-)
